Bacterial infections (e.g., scarlet fever, Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome)

Drug Reaction (with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms - DRESS)
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) Acute Retroviral Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of your skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Often, it starts with flu-like symptoms, followed by a painful red or purplish rash that spreads and blisters.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening skin disorder that causes blistering and peeling of the skin. It can be thought of as a more severe form of Stevens-Johnson Syndrome. It typically involves more than 30% of the body surface area.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: An acute febrile illness of unknown etiology that primarily affects children younger than 5 years of age. Features can include fever, conjunctivitis, erythema of the lips and mouth, rash, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening condition often characterized by rash, fever, eosinophilia, and involvement of internal organs. It can initially be confused with a simple drug rash.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause severe fatigue and joint pain. It can also cause a distinctive rash, often on the face, and may affect the internal organs, including the kidneys and heart.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
diagnoses.description: A mild childhood illness caused by Parvovirus B19. It presents with a slapped cheek rash on the face and a lacy pattern of redness on the arms, legs, and trunk.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease resulting from a group A streptococcus infection, known as strep throat. Scarlet fever features a red rash that feels like sandpaper and a high fever.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the small blood vessels that causes them to bleed into the skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys. Characteristically, it causes a purple rash (purpura), abdominal pain, and kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Acute Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which red blood cells are destroyed and removed from the bloodstream before their normal lifespan is over. This can be triggered by infections, autoimmune diseases, or exposure to certain drugs.

diagnoses.name: Graft vs Host Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when donor bone marrow or stem cells attack the recipient. It can result in skin rashes, liver dysfunction, and gastrointestinal symptoms.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Viral Infections (e.g., Herpes Simplex Virus, Epstein-Barr Virus)

Drug reactions (e.g., drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms [DRESS] syndrome)
Viral exanthems (various viral infections can present with these symptoms)
Erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease, caused by Parvovirus B19)
Infectious mononucleosis (caused by the Epstein-Barr virus)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Reactive Thrombocytosis
diagnoses.description: An elevated platelet count, which may occur as a reactive process to another underlying condition such as infection, inflammation, or cancer.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition more common in children under 5, causing inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It is associated with fever, conjunctivitis, rash, red, swollen hands and feet, and red, cracked lips or strawberry tongue.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono, this infection is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus and can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, fever, inflamed throat, swollen lymph nodes, and in some cases, an elevated platelet count.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pharyngitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pharynx caused by a viral infection. Symptoms can include sore throat (oropharyngeal erythema), fever, and conjunctivitis.

diagnoses.name: Streptococcal Pharyngitis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that can cause a sore and red throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes, often accompanied by an elevated platelet count as part of the body's reaction to infection.

diagnoses.name: Adenovirus Infection
diagnoses.description: An infection caused by adenovirus that can present a wide range of symptoms including cold-like symptoms, sore throat, bronchitis, pneumonia, diarrhea, and conjunctivitis.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: A disease resulting from a group A streptococcus infection, known for a distinctive rash, fever, a red and sore throat, and in some cases, an elevated platelet count.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that affects white blood cells. It can lead to an abnormal increase in platelets (thrombocytosis) among other diverse symptoms depending on the type.

diagnoses.name: Bone Marrow Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders affecting the bone marrow can lead to abnormal production of blood cells, including an elevated number of platelets. Symptoms and associated conditions can vary widely.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: A disease that can develop after an infection with group A streptococcus bacteria. It can cause a variety of symptoms including fever, painful and tender joints, rash, and in some cases, an elevated platelet count.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia + Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Schizophrenia (in the context of psychosis, considering other symptoms may go beyond primary psychiatric disorders)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Primary Immune Thrombocytopenia
diagnoses.details: A disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding, resulting from unusually low levels of platelets. This can cause symptoms like epistaxis and menorrhagia, potentially linking to dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own tissues. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including dyspnea, immune abnormalities like increased immunoglobulins, and potentially menstrual abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.details: A bleeding disorder that can cause excessive bleeding, including heavy menstrual bleeding (dysmenorrhea) and nosebleeds (epistaxis).

diagnoses.name: Hemophilia
diagnoses.details: A rare disorder in which your blood doesn't clot normally because it lacks sufficient blood-clotting proteins. This could result in symptoms such as epistaxis and potentially exacerbated menstrual bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.details: This is an immune disorder marked by recurrent episodes of severe swelling. While not directly related to dysmenorrhea, it could potentially correlate with immunoglobulin abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.details: This condition might follow from chronic blood loss due to heavy menstrual periods and nosebleeds, leading to symptoms like dyspnea on exertion.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. It can be associated with immune system problems and can cause dyspnea and cognitive impairments such as difficulty maintaining attention.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.details: A condition that affects a woman's hormone levels, which can cause irregular menstrual periods, excess hair growth, and obesity. It is a leading cause of dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.details: A blood disorder characterized by a decrease in the number of platelets in the blood. Symptoms include easy or excessive bruising and bleeding, such as epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.details: While primarily affecting mental health, anxiety can manifest with physical symptoms such as shortness of breath and can exacerbate or be confused with attention deficits. Though a less direct link, chronic stress and anxiety can also affect menstrual cycles.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing symptoms like malabsorption and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental health condition characterized by persistent sadness, lack of interest in activities, and can cause physical problems such as chronic pain.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A common disorder affecting the large intestine, causing symptoms like cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea or constipation, sometimes leading to malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Lactose Intolerance
diagnoses.description: An inability to digest lactose, a sugar found in milk and dairy products, leading to symptoms like diarrhea, gas, and bloating.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) damages the immune system and can lead to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS), causing symptoms like lymphadenitis, hypersensitivity reactions, and malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the glands that make moisture, it often accompanies other autoimmune disorders, like celiac disease, and can cause dryness, malabsorption, and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition, often accompanying depression and immune system-related symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It can be associated with symptoms of depression and sensitivity to pain.

diagnoses.name: Vulvovaginal Atrophy
diagnoses.description: Thinning, drying, and inflammation of the vaginal walls due to decreased estrogen. In some cases, it can lead to vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: An umbrella term for disorders that involve chronic inflammation of the digestive tract, such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, causing malabsorption and various systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism may not cause noticeable symptoms in the early stages, but over time, untreated hypothyroidism can cause a number of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility, and heart disease.

diagnoses.name: Graves' disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that causes hyperthyroidism, or overactive thyroid. With this disease, your immune system attacks the thyroid and causes it to make more thyroid hormone than your body needs.

diagnoses.name: Type 2 diabetes
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose). Though not directly causing gastroparesis, diabetes complications can sometimes result in nerve damage which in turn can lead to gastroparesis.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs from exposure to high cortisol levels for a long time. The most common cause is the use of steroid hormones such as prednisone for a long time.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods or excess male hormone (androgen) levels.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. It can lead to various emotional and physical problems and can decrease a person’s ability to function at work and at home.

diagnoses.name: Sleep apnea
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts. Risk factors include obesity, smoking, and high blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)
diagnoses.description: A condition in which an abnormal protein (known as monoclonal protein or M protein) is in the blood. MGUS itself is usually harmless, but it can precede or indicate a more serious disease.

diagnoses.name: Myelodysplastic syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders caused by poorly formed or dysfunctional blood cells. Risk factors include previous chemotherapy or radiation therapy.

diagnoses.name: Chronic fatigue syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complicated disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue may worsen with physical or mental activity, but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.reason: Symptoms including bloating are common; related dysautonomia can affect blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.reason: Bloating and dysgeusia can be symptoms due to malabsorption and the body's reaction to gluten.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Connective tissue diseases can present Lymphadenopathy, dysgeusia, and blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Cancer
diagnoses.reason: In advanced stages, can cause bloating, dysgeusia, and Lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis (Mono)
diagnoses.reason: Commonly presents with Lymphadenopathy; can also cause dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reason: Early dissemination can present with Lymphadenopathy, dysgeusia, and varying symptoms including blood pressure changes.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Primary symptoms can include dysgeusia due to dry mouth; also related to autoimmune dysfunction that could lead to Lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: Characterized by Lymphadenopathy; can indirectly cause dysgeusia and blood pressure issues.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: Similar to Hodgkin's but with a broader symptom profile including Lymphadenopathy and possibly dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Can cause bloating, and indirectly affect blood pressure; might relate to tags (assuming referring to skin changes/tags).

diagnoses: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) / Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Common Cold or Upper Respiratory Tract Infection

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines with aura are headaches accompanied by sensory disturbances that can include scotoma, scintillation, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA may cause sudden symptom onset including dysarthria, numbness, and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the brain and spinal cord, leading to symptoms like numbness, paresthesia, and sometimes scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A brain attack that occurs when blood flow to an area of the brain is cut off, can cause dysarthria, numbness, and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, which can include scintillation and temporary numbness.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulging, weakened area in the wall of an artery in the brain, potentially causing paresthesia, scotoma, and other neurological symptoms if it leaks or bursts.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause numbness, dysarthria, and other neurological symptoms depending on its location.

diagnoses.name: Hemiplegic Migraine
diagnoses.description: A rare form of migraine where people experience weakness on one side of the body in addition to the migraine headache, and can include symptoms like numbness and scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect the nervous system, leading to symptoms like scotoma, paresthesia, and dysarthria.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause scotoma among other visual disturbances, often associated with multiple sclerosis.

diagnoses: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may cause symptoms such as paralysis, speech difficulties, and other problems.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including mobility and speech difficulties, along with weakness and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can be cancerous (malignant) or noncancerous (benign). They can cause symptoms such as headaches, seizures, problems with vision, vomiting, and mental changes.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as a 'mini-stroke,' a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a significant primary headache disorder often characterized by recurrent headaches that are moderate to severe. Aura may include visual disturbances or other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: Cerebral vasculitis is an inflammation of the blood vessel walls in the brain or spine. Symptoms may include headaches, confusion, seizures, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection. Symptoms might include headache, fever, and neurological deficits.

diagnoses.name: Primary Progressive Aphasia
diagnoses.description: Primary progressive aphasia is a rare neurological syndrome that impairs language capabilities. It often starts with difficulty naming objects or finding words and progresses to more severe communication difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi transmitted to humans through a tick bite. It can lead to various symptoms, sometimes including neurological problems like weakness and impaired muscle movement.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is a rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms. It can sometimes lead to paralysis.

Hepatitis B and C Related Cryoglobulinemic Vasculitis
Vasculitis (e.g., microscopic polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Hepatitis B or C associated cryoglobulinemia
